title: gcode converter to make Cura dual extrusion work with Sailfish

description.text:
I use Cura 15.02.1 as a slicer... But I have a dual extrusion printer running Sailfish (7.5) firmware too. They work fine together as long as you only do single extrusion. If you move to dual extrusion you will quickly realise that it will not work... and perhaps you will even look for alternatives to Cura. The problem is that:
  • Cura handles dual extrusion E-values as a combined total.
  • Sailfish handles dual extrusion E-values a total per extruder.
    This results in big blobs of plastic and extruder skipping steps at each tool change.
    • I have notified the Cura developers of this problem (it does not have high prio to be fixed), but in the meanwhile I have made a converter to fix this issue. Perhaps I'll make it into a Cura plugin, we'll see... Ok, so what should you do?
  • Save your Cura merged dual extrusion as gcode (Cura set to GCode flavour = MakerBot)
  • Run the converter and load the gcode
  • The converter will produce a gcode file ending with "fixed" in the filename
  • Convert the fixed gcode to g3x using gpx (I use r1d as gpx setting)
  • Print your Cura generated dual extrusion model
    • The converter may work with gcode produced by other slicers as well. The converter looks for tool change (only 2 tools supported though) and keeps track of the extruded amount per extruder. I have tested the converter with the 2 stl files in the thingfiles - merged them in cura - saved gcode - used my converter - used gpx - and printed successfully. Do not run the fixed gcode through the converter again, you will just mess up the gcode - one time through the converter will do just fine. Oh..! and do not come running back with complaints or ruined printers or whatever. I made this program for myself - if you use it, you do it totally at your own risk.

comments.text: installed it and created the fix file (despite my computer itself, and Norton telling me to uninstall and not use this) and uploaded the new gcode to replicatorg to still find the same errors in the code. I'm not sure if we getting same errors. The error is "Unrecognized MCode! M135" which is stated to be the toolchange command.
comments.author: nickdzi

comments.text: Hi nickdzi
comments.author: nickdzi

comments.text: I'll have a look at it when I get some time. If I remember correctly M135 is not understood by all slicers/firmware, so check that first.

title: Sun Flower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: For this project, I made a blue sunflower.  This will be used as decoration.

1) I made this project in inventor
2) I created a new sketch, and made the first layer. Which includes the circle and first set of petals
3) Then, I extruded the first layer 0.06
4) After, I made the second set of petals and extruded them 0.06
5) I saved my project as an STL
6) I was ready to print on the makerbot, so I had to generate a G code
7) The last thing I did after the g code was generated was build my project

title: Hinged Fan extension for "Printrbot Simple, 300mm Y Axis-No Sag!"

description.text:
This is a hinged version of FablabMoebius' Fan extension for
iamjonlawrence's Y axis No Sag design. I loved FablabMoebius' solution to keep the iamjonlawrence's
YFront piece from getting too hot and deforming, but found that
the fan was in the way if I needed to access the extruder to change
filament or to clear a jam, etc. My solution was to make this a hinged part. It's a print in place
hinge so no worries about it coming apart during a print. I now
have the cooling I want without giving up easy access to the
extruder. I also rounded a few of the corners, added a cable tie loop for wire
management, and got rid of the lip on the upright piece that made it
difficult to connect to the printer. Printing details are on the instructions tab Update: While this doesn't happen to the one I printed, someone
told me that theirs moves around while printing and asked for a way
to keep it in place, so I added a second file
(SwivelFanMountWithPegs.stl) which has two pegs you can use to
secure it with a small rubber band. I haven't printed this one yet,
but the changes are minor and I don't expect any problems with it.

You need a well calibrated printer to get the hinge to work. I had to
print this upright with support (rotate the part 90 degrees on the
X axis.) I printed in PLA with support and .2mm layers and 40% infill. Use an M3x20 screw for the top mounting hole and M3X16 screws
for the others. I have a heatbed, so I set it to 50 degrees for the first few layers and
adjusted it to 40 degrees for the remainder of the print (but I don't
think a heatbed is absolutely necessary if printing this in PLA.) Once printed, break off the support material and then carefully bend
the part back and forth in the direction the hinge would rotate. You
should feel the hinge break free.

author: Raylione

description.text: By request, this is the famous, fabulous lampshade script. We've used it to produce lampshades, bracelets, faux ABS LPs, small storage cups, and in any situation where a hollow cylindrical or conical form optionally with a solid bottom is called for. This script takes an image file as input and produces a gcode file that will create a conical form of the specified parameters, with the image embossed on the surface. It's recommended that you use the -c flag, which will cause the form to be built as a single, continuous spiral. You may need to edit the script or its output to add your own pre- and post- print gcodes. Be sure to cast an eye over the output before you print! Printing these forms in clear PLA is particularly pleasing! The code is maintained in git; the latest version is always available at: https://github.com/makerbot/Makerbot/tree/master/scripts/lampshade Have fun!

Here's the usage info. Go crazy!
Usage: lampshade.py [options] image.png Options:
-h, --help show this help message and exit
-r RADIUS, --radius=RADIUS
set the top and bottom radius of a right cylinder
-l LAYERHEIGHT, --layerheight=LAYERHEIGHT
set the height of a single layer, in mm
--rtop=RTOP set the top radius of a conical shade
--rbot=RBOT set the bottom radius of a conical shade
-H HEIGHT, --height=HEIGHT
set the height of the shade
-s SPEEDFACTOR, --speed-factor=SPEEDFACTOR
the factor to multiply the feedrate by for a
completely dark pixel
-c, --continuous use continuous Z movement
-a, --ABP use automated build platform
--bottom-layers=BOTTOM
number of layers in the floor
-f FEEDRATE, --feedrate=FEEDRATE
set the base feedrate

title: i3v X Carriage and Fan shroud

description.text:
This is a replacement i3v X Carriage and fan shroud for the MakerFarm i3v. One is a direct replacement, the no eccentric one removes the x carriage eccentric for a sliding mount instead. The no eccentric mount is superior and is the one I suggest you use. This new carriage supports auto bed leveling, the Hexagon and the Pico hotends (the pico is 20mm longer) has a mount in the back for LED lighting and lots of room for airflow from high CFM cooling fans. The overall design is a single piece and is very stiff but should be printed in PETG or ABS.
The 4 large holes can be used for wire management allowing cables to be run directly out of the back of the carriage or the side keeping appearances clean and allowing for additional airflow across the cold end.
The Fan shroud is specific to the Pico hotend and uses 4mm magnets to hold the fan to the assembly.
The Material Fan can mount between the main fan shroud and your fan to allow air to be directed to both the material being printed and the hotend without requiring a second fan. If you use the material fan you must use a 10+ CFM fan.
Keep ahold of the Derlin wheels and axels. You don't need to use magnets to mount the fan, screws will work fine.

description.text: UPdate: The remixes of this item are vastly superior to what I produced. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795954 in particular has taken this to the next level. I would download it instead. This is a z mount for the MakerFarm i3v that helps to reduce z wobble and potentially backlash. It also frees up about 25mm of X travel because the original mounts are a little over sized. You'll need a 50mm spring to hold the nut in place but can reuse the original nuts.
After you print the piece, press the original nut into the mount carrier and then insert the spring into the recess to hold it in place. You want the nut at the top of the x carriage.

The design of the Deltaprintr means the stepper motors touches the lower surface that the printer is standing on. This is a design for small feet that push-fit onto the ends of the uprights, allowing the Maker to easily stick felt/rubber pads onto the bottom. This has a few added benefits
  • it lifts the printer a little up off the surface so the steppers don't transfer heat to the surface it is standing on
  • it helps baffle the vibration noise of the printer
  • the design of the cut-out keeps the end-stop cables from getting snagged

For easier printing, lie the piece on it's back before slicing.  
The cable management feature will then be easier and cleaner to print.

description.text:
Watch the video: https://youtu.be/8qM3Bao3zJQ UPDATE: You can now buy all of the non-printed parts for this thing from:
https://www.freewebstore.org/assemble-store
(note: I am not affiliated with assemble.network) This fiendishly clever walking toy was invented by my friend John Jameson back in 1981. It mechanically couples a spinning gyroscope (thru some gearing) to a pair of feet that stomp up and down. When one foot goes down, the body actually lifts up and then starts to precess clockwise. Then when the other foot comes down the body lifts again but this time precesses counterclockwise - and voila, it walks! All the parts you need (bearings, screws, etc.) are listed in the instructions, including the 104 pennies used for the flywheel mass. I've included a 3D PDF file which will let you view the entire assembly from all angles, hide components, etc. This 3D printable version that I designed is kinematically a little different from the original, but you can read the history of the original at: http://cyberneticzoo.com/walking-machines/1981-the-walking-gyro-john-w-jameson-american/

UPDATE: I've added a flywheel that works with 0.02 Euro coins. Also note that RobertCL has done a flywheel remix for 1p UK coins: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:794106 You will need the following parts:
2 side.stl
1 flywheel.stl
1 retainingring.stl
1 pulley.stl
1 eccentric.stl
4 bar.stl
1 link.stl
2 leg_short.stl
2 foot.stl
1 collar.stl
1 hook.stl
1 pullring.stl
20 4-40 x 3/8" pan head screws (McMaster 90272A108)
1 4-40 x 5/8" pan head screw
10 3mm bore, 10mm OD, 4mm thick ball bearings (623ZZ)
......(I purchased 10 for $2.15 at http://www.ebay.com/itm/161255478926)
4 #4 washer, 0.22 OD x 0.031 thick (McMaster 90295A359)
1 3mm rod x 1.9" long (McMaster 5544T222)
1 3mm rod x 2.5" long (McMaster 5544T222)
4 O-rings 1/16" thick x 1 7/8 OD (McMaster 9452K118)
3ft 30# test Spectra braided fishing line
superglue
104 pennies Before starting, take a good look at the 3D PDF file gyroman3d.pdf. It will give you a good idea of how everything goes together.

  • Acquire all the parts. You can buy most of the hardware from mcmaster.com (I've listed their part numbers), although it may be cheaper if you can find some of the items in a hardware or hobby store. For the pennies, I'd recommend getting 2 rolls of brand-new pennies. Pennies are suppose to weigh exactly 2.5g, but I've found a number of them tipping the scale at 3g.

  • Print all of the parts. I used PLA, 0.2mm layers, 3 perimeters and 30% infill, except for the flywheel where I used 20% infill. All of the parts need to be pretty flat, so if you don't have a heated bed, use a raft 3-4 mm tall.

  • Press 2 bearings into each side, one bearing into each foot, and 2 bearings (stacked) into the eccentric. Use a vise or arbor press because you don't want them to get cocked as you are pressing them in. If you don't have either, you can carefully tap them in with a hammer.

  • Fit two of the O-rings into the grooves on the feet. This is kind of tricky. Once in place, run a tiny bead of superglue along the top edge to hold the O-ring in place.

  • Screw the feet to the bottoms of the legs with a washer between the bearing and the leg. Screw the 4 bars onto the legs, and then screw the link between the 4 bars. Tighten the screws all the way and then back off 1/8 turn so that the legs can pivot up and down freely.

  • Assemble 13 pennies into each slot in the flywheel. Make sure the entire stack it sitting flat (it's a tight fit). Fit the retaining ring over the pennies, snapping it into place (another tight fit). The retaining ring should be flush with the top of the flywheel. Use a few drops of superglue on each stack of pennies to hold them in place. (If the pennies rattle, you'll lose flywheel energy.)

  • Press the short 3mm rod onto the pulley, with one bearing thickness of the shaft sticking out one end. Press the collar onto the other end of the short shaft, again, with one bearing thickness of shaft sticking out the end. Press the long 3mm shaft into the flywheel, with one bearing thickness plus one washer thickness protruding from one end. (If you don't get a tight fit with flywheel on the rod, you can secure the rod with a 4-40 setscrew.)

  • Put a washer over the short end flywheel axle and insert into the center bearing on one side. Place one O-ring over the small pulley on the flywheel. Insert the collar-end of the pulley axle into the other bearing, going thru the O-Ring. (Don't try to fit the O-Ring into the pulley groove yet.) Place another O-ring over the small diameter groove in the pulley and also over the flywheel axle. Now slide the eccentric onto the flywheel axle. (Don't try to fit the O-ring into place yet.) Put one more washer on the end of the flywheel shaft.

  • Slide the other side onto the two axles and loosely screw the two sides together. Work the first O-ring up and over the large diameter groove in the pulley. The second O-ring is a little trickier. There is a little nub on the eccentric that you can hook the O-ring on. Then rotate the eccentric around until the O-ring is pulled around the diameter of the eccentric. Tighten the screws holding the two sides together. At this point you should be able to spin the flywheel and everything should rotate smoothly.

  • Screw the leg assembly onto the body with the link on the side with the eccentric. Now place a bearing in the eccentric slot and push it so that it exactly lines up with the slot in the side piece. Tip the body on its side so that the bearing drops into the slot in the side piece. Slide the bearing up or down so that it stays captured in the slot in the side. Stick a second bearing in the eccentric slot and push it so that it again lines up with the slot in the side. Now push the first bearing so that it exactly overlaps with the second bearing. Insert the long 4-40 screw into the link and screw it in so that it goes through the bores of both bearings. The screw should be almost touching the bottom of the slot in the eccentric.

  • Tap the hook onto the end of the flywheel axle. Tie a loop in one end of the fishing line. Tie the other end of the fishing line to the pullring. CAUTION - Do not pull on the fishing line with your bare hands. It is extremely strong and extremely thin, and it will cut your hand to ribbons!

  • Hook the loop end of the fishing line over the hook and then spin the pulley to wrap the line up on the axle. Try to keep the wraps neat. Now let-er rip!

comments.author: LukeTansell

comments.text: It's more typical for small, high speed bearings to have a very light oil rather than grease.  If they seem gummed up, you could try soaking them in something like WD40 and see if that loosens them up.  There's not much of a load on them so they don't really need much lubrication.  You should also check to make sure that nothing is binding or rubbing anywhere (you shouldn't hear any scraping).
comments.author: LukeTansell

comments.text: In step 3 we put all the bearings in all the pieces, but then in step 10 it mentions putting bearings in again.  I tried it the first way, putting bearings in on step 3 and found step  9 to be very hard.  I measured the rod that McMaster sent and it measures 2.99-3.02 (depending on how firm I am with the calipers) and the bearings measure 2.99mm so it's possible McMcaster just sent me a rod that's a little too big. Would that 0.02mm be enough to make it impossible to use this rod and slide it through the bearings on the side piece?
comments.author: ualdayan

comments.text: Yes, you can definitely get problems with the shafts not sliding smoothly onto the bearing, both from the shaft being oversized and the bearings being undersized.  (I had one set of 3mm bearings that wouldn't slide over the same shaft that worked fine with a different set of 3mm bearings.)  Usually, though, it is pretty easy to reduce the shaft diameter by a tiny amount with some 400 grit emory paper.  I'll put the shaft in a drill and then sand a bit and then test with a bearing until the bearing will just slide over the entire length.
comments.author: ualdayan

comments.text: I sanded them down, but I still don't quite understand what happens in step 10.  My side of the eccentric is only deep enough for 1 bearing on the side (2 are in the middle - the ones put in on step 3), but it sounds like step 10 wants you to put 2 bearings on the side as well?
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: In step 10, you have one bearing that rides in the slot in the eccentric, and the second bearing rides in the slot in the side piece.  The two bearings end up side-by-side, but they are sliding in slots in different parts.  If this is not clear, look at the Gyroman3D.pdf file.  With the 3D PDF, you can selectively hide some parts (or even make them transparent) so that you can see what's going on inside the assembly.
comments.author: ualdayan

title: Universal Adjustable Phone and Small Tablet Stand EDITED & FIXED

description.text:
Universal Adjustable Phone and Small Tablet Stand NOTICE: I had an issue with the side pieces not being mirrored on file #3... I've taken care of the issue and everything should work now!! Thanks! My remix of bobamason's model, INCLUDING assembly pins! • Holds most larger phones and small tablets.
• Adjustable from about 50 degrees to 90 degrees.
• Loose pins for easy movement.
• Includes three separate, editable STL files
• Includes one full model, ready-to-print STL for a single print ~ (Read instructions for helpful notes!) ~

IMPORTANT / HELPFUL NOTES: • ALL 3 FILES ARE SIZED TO FIT EACH OTHER initially.
If you are going to change the scale of your print, make sure you
do it equally for ALL 3 STL files or your pieces won't fit together!
OR, simply use the "Full Model (Single Print).stl" file. • Remember to sand pieces if necessary • Print with a 3-4mm brim (at least on file 3, so the pins don't fall
over) • Glue pin "caps" onto each pin end to better secure your print Instructions for Assembly: 1) Print all 3 of the separate STL files. (For smaller print beds) OR print the "Full Model (Single Print).stl". (For bigger print beds) 2) Insert one pin into the hole of the "base" piece, and the second pin into the hole of the "adjustment lock". (Pins are the same size) 3) Attach the two "side" pieces to the "base" piece, then attach the "adjustment lock" to the side pieces as depicted in the picture of the completed print. 4) Apply the pin "caps" to both protruding ends of each pin. Test the rotation of the adjustment pieces. If necessary, secure the pin "caps" onto the pins with some glue. Enjoy! ~ Check out bobamason's original model!

title: 3D prostetic Hand with flexible joints not screws or springs

description.text: So this was my second setup for a young man named Sam. He needed it to be motorized so I did that. This setup works well with strings as well I recommend using the NinjaFlex material for joints and wrist attachments since its so much more ergonomic. Besides the flex joints I also learned that I can pair 2 fingers up so that they can make better use of their grip. If you loop the string from one finger to the one next to it you can continue to close the grip even when one finger has made a connection with the object. Picture grabbing a ball and the outside 2 fingers should close further than the middle 2. With the looped concept you can achieve that. Ok so this is a project that is pretty close to being left or right hand dependent based on how you assemble the pieces. I like the motor option so we are rolling with that design for right now since there are so many string pull setups out there. Just take those concepts and add the NinjaFlex material for your joints etc. More to come.. Here is a video of the setup in action... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ypzqbA05EMY

So you print the Main Hand, motor mount, motor wheel, 5 sets of fingers and 5 sets of nuckles. You need a couple wrist attachements but may just design your own based on the arm of the user. I put some out there just for examples. The nuckles and wrist parts are printed with NinjaFlex material. Mark your finger joints in a way that you know which go to what when you take them off the platform. Notice the fingers as well and what order they go. I am finishing up a thumb I am trying to get creative to where you can rotate it about 40 degrees so it can go from the hand shake position to grab a bottle position. - Coming Soon The wheel has 3 holes these are for eyelets to be heated up and inserted so the string can be attached and also looped for the custom grip talked about where 2 fingers work as pairs. You need one of these... http://www.superdroidrobots.com/shop/item.aspx/pololu-200-to-1-plastic-gear-motor-90-degree-output/1306/ One of these...
http://www.temcoindustrialpower.com/products/Limit_Switches/CN0099.html A 9 volt battery wire harness....
http://www.lowes.com/pd_364309-37672-884476_0__?productId=3478193&Ntt=9v+battery+harness&pl=1&currentURL=%3FNtt%3D9v%2Bbattery%2Bharness&facetInfo= Some of these to cut up and glue on to palm and fingers for grip....
http://www.officedepot.com/a/products/964460/Swingline-Rubber-Fingertips-14-78-Diameter/?cm_mmc=PLA-_-Google-_-Mailing_Shipping_Envelopes-_-964460-VQ6-42102187796-VQ16c-VQ17-pla-VQ18-online-VQ19-964460-VQ20-73462265929-VQ21- The Thumb swivel is still something I am going to play with its a new feature but I would like it to swivel and be in a hand shaking position or a ball grabbing position, then swivel back and be a bottle or handle grabbing position. You would just pivot it with your other hand as needed. I use at least 50 lbs test fishing line for the strings, the finger tip has a small revine in it so you can super glue the string down when tensioned properly, then the rubber fingers go over it so its out of sight out of mind. This glue is da bomb for this stuff..... http://www.loctiteproducts.com/p/sg_plstc/overview/Loctite-Plastics-Bonding-System.htm Like I say more to come.. but wanted to get started.. hit me with the questions.

title: RigidBot Dual Extruder Plate & Mount (no X loss)

description.text:
***UPDATED MODEL = thing:769147.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769147 This is a dual extruder mount and X-axis plate. It is unique in that there is zero loss in build volume in the X-axis. The second extruder is mounted with only a Y-offset to do this. I wanted to keep the full 16" on the rigidbot big build plate.
Mounting is easy, simply print these 3 pieces and mount your two (or one) e3d-v6 in the slots. Then thread 3 M3 bolts through the neck pieces along the top (note that the two necks are not exactly identical). Tighten a nut on there and it should stay snug. The whole plate then mounts with the exact same footprint as the original single extruder aluminum plate.

Mounting is easy, simply print these 3 pieces and mount your two (or one) e3d-v6 in the slots. Then thread 3 M3 bolts through the neck pieces along the top (note that the two necks are not exactly identical). Tighten a nut on there and it should stay snug. description.text: This is the unofficial "Dragonfly" extension piece for the game Hive. It's based on my Hive piece template. This model is also available on Shapeways.
This design is loosely based on the Solder-Mill with a roller and hole to feed solder through.

Print 2 of the nibs (solid) and 1 roller and 1 base. I would make the roller around 20% infill and the base solid.  
Then glue the nibs into the end of the roller, if you print in ABS (preferred) then you can just use a few drops of acetone, the rounded end of the nibs point outward.  
Simply feed solder through hole in front, slide roller into roll of solder and slide into place.
A simple device so that you can hold a book with one hand.

description.text: This is another version of the pencil sculpture.  This time the rods look more like pencils

This is a filament feed tube holder that mounts to the Taz 4-5 carriage.  I was snapping some brittle filament at times as the carriage moved back and forth.  The weak point was where the feed tube just lays against the top of the idler arm forming a fulcrum point which may snap some filaments like Laybrick for example.  
This holder mounts to the extruder mount plate and accepts the end of the feed tube.  It will flex slightly as the carriage moves but it will hold the tube more or less vertical forcing the tube to bend instead.  This spreads the load out along the feed tube thus reducing any small hinge points.  
It has a split retainer ring so filament and tube are easily removed without having to thread it through the holder or remove the holder at any time.  
You will need a M3x16 screw to replace the M3x12 that the Taz currently uses to hold the extruder plate onto the carriage.  The current screw is simply too short.  No other modifications are needed.  
The tube holder is sized to fit the feed tube that came with my Taz 5.  It is slightly oversized at the top to make it easier to insert the tube.  If you are using a feed tube with a different diameter, you will need to either drill the holder out or edit the mesh to enlarge the internal diameter.  I made sure the polys are clean so resizing in a mesh editor should be fairly easy.  
5/1/15 - Added 3 additional file types for download.

It is designed to print 90 degrees from the way the STL has it.  I left it vertical so you could see the split ring.  It should lay flat to print.  
I printed mine in ABS at 0.2mm layers, 25% infill, 4 perimeters and 4 top/bottom layers.  That should give it the stiffness to hold well but still allow some flex in the arm.

title: 30mm/40mm Fan Adaptor for Taz with Hexagon Hot End

description.text:
This is a new fan shroud and extruder mounting plate that will replace the tiny squirrel cage fan thats excessively noisy. You will need to print out either the 30mm or 40mm Fan shroud (nocap) and the new extruder mount plate. The other STLs are there in case anyone wants to make a derivative work from them. The only support you will need is in the tiny notch on the tip of the fan shroud. The extruder mount is adapted from the stock Lulzbot extruder mount plate STL that was supplied with my Taz 5. The fan shroud duct is my own creation. See the instructions tab for correct fan ordering and a full parts list of what hardware you will need to complete the build. Here are a couple videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9k8HNd6Luqg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=01mz3FG8cFg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kcP5SsKEs3w

Parts List
==================== The following hardware list assumes you would be converting an existing single hex extruder head from Lulz and would be using the extruder assembly, existing 40mm fan and all existing wiring and connectors. Fan
Here is my chosen fan (Evercool 30x30x7 ball bearing 5v):
http://www.evercoolusa.com/?p=678 And the ebay link:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/121149126099 Other hardware:
8x m3x3.8mm Heat Sets
2x m3x10mm Hex screws (attach shroud to extuder mount)
2x m3 washers
4x m3x10mm Pan Head screws (can use hex but pan gives more lateral clearance to the z limit switch/wiring)
1x 2 Pin connector
2x Pins for the above connector
Heat shrink tubing
Wire ties
2x 33ohm 1/8w or 1x 15ohm 1/4w resistor (optional if you want to cut down the rpms and sound level even more) Optional:
These are for the wiretie to hold it to the aluminum plate, seen below with a bread twistie temporarily.
1x m3x8mm Hex screw
1x m3 washer Printed Parts:
Fan Shroud (shown in orange in the images)
Extruder Mount plate (shown in green in the images) I played with some resistors in series and I like 15 to 16ohms. It cuts the rpms down and the noise but still leaves way more airflow than the dinky little fan the Taz had. I have two 33ohm in parallel to get 16ohms. They are 1/8w so that gives me 1/4w dissipation across the two. Ran it off a PC supply for 2 hours and the resistors never changed temp that I could tell with my fingers. No changes are made to the Taz itself and this mod is 100% reversible. You will make no changes to any Taz5 part that is not reversible. If you wish to return to the stock setup, simply transfer all your parts back to the stock mounting plate and print on! Assembly
==================== Print the two parts:
  • WolfieExtruderMount.STL
  • WolfFanDuctAssembled30_noCap.STL
    • Once they are printed and you have assured yourself you have all the necessary hardware purchased continue.. Disassemble your existing Taz extruder head:
  • Snip the filament off above the extruder leaving it in place through the extruder into the hot end. This will maintain extruder to hot end alignment.
  • Remove the head from the Taz
  • Snip any wire ties on the wires.
  • Remove the stock fan shroud (leaving fan attached), set shroud, fan and 2 screws/washers aside for use later.
  • Remove the extruder from the mount plate and set the extruder and 2 screws/washers aside for use later.
  • Set the extruder plate with the small squirrel cage fan aside, it will not be used for this build but you should keep it in case anything goes awry with the rebuild.
    • Assemble the new head:
  • Apply the 4 heat sets to the new printed mounting plate, two on each side.
  • Apply the remaining 4 heat sets to the new fan shroud.
  • Seat the extruder and hot end in place on the new mount.
  • Finger tighten ONLY the two mounting screws for the extruder/hot end.
  • Mount the newly printed fan shroud while turning and aligning the Hexagon fins and set screw so they properly align to the new shroud cutout.
  • Tighten the exposed hot end mounting screw fully.
  • Remove the fan shroud.
  • Tighten the second hot end mounting screw fully.
  • Mount the new 30mm fan on the new duct.
  • Snip the YELLOW wire off about 1/2" from the fan case, its not used for this build.
  • Snip the connector off the end of the black and red wires and discard, its not used.
  • Slip a 1" length of larger diameter piece of heat shrink tubing over the wires including the yellow one.
  • Cut a length of smaller diameter heat shrink tubing to length so it leaves 2" of the fan wires exposed at the end.
  • Slip the smaller diameter of heat shrink tubing over the wires and ensure it goes inside the larger diameter tubing which should butt up against the fan housing.
  • Using a lighter, shrink the two pieces of heat shrink down to lock them in place. You should now have all wires covered except for 2" at the end where the connector was.
  • Cut another piece of larger heat shrink tubing 2" long. A little more if you got it.
  • Slip it over the wires but DO NOT HEAT! Leave it loose! Simply slide it down by the fan out of the way for now.
  • Strip 1/8" of insulation off the end of the black wire.
  • Solder it to a pin and crimp the captive tabs down to support it.
  • If you used two 1/8W resistors, twist the wire of one around the wire of the other very close to the resistor body.
  • Twist the other end in the same way making the second resistor piggy back on top of the first.
  • Solder them at each end close to the resistor body.
  • Snip off the excess wire from the second resistor, leaving the straight leads of the first resistor.
  • Trim one lead down leaving approximately 1/8" remaining.
  • Solder it to the second pin and crimp the captive tabs down to support it.
  • Trim the second lead down leaving a bit more than 1/8" or so.
  • Trim the red wire back by the length of the exposed resistors from the base of the pin to the base of the resistor away from the connector pin. This will allow both the red and black wire to be approximately the same length and keep the pins straight.
  • Strip 1/8" insulation from the red wire and tin it.
  • Solder the red wire to the remaining resistor lead.
  • Check that the two pins are positioned approximately inline. If not, unsolder the red wire and adjust its length to correct.
  • Holding the connector with the end that you insert the pins into facing you and the open end facing away, insert the black wire pin into the right channel.
  • Insert the red wire pin into the left channel.
  • Use the squirrel cage fan wire and connector as reference.
  • Once you are sure you have the polarity correct, push each pin into the housing until it clicks in place.
  • Slide the loose heat shrink tubing up to cover the resistors and heat it to lock it in place. No exposed wires should be seen.
  • Install the assembled fan/shroud onto the mounting plate and tighten it down fully.
  • Install the 40mm cooling fan/shroud you removed from your existing head and fully tighten it down. Be sure not to pinch the heater and thermistor wires.
  • Route all wires up and put new wire tie(s) in place like they were when you cut them.
  • MARK the new fan lead with a yellow indicator. I used yellow wire ties. Yellow paint or stickers work too. Just be sure you can identify this connector from the cooling fan connector. It MUST plug into the Taz harness connector with the yellow dot. The yellow dot connector has only 5v on it. The cooling fan connector has 24v on it and will toast the new fan and/or resistors if plugged in to the cooling fan connector.
    • At this point you should have a fully working extruder head. Before attaching it to your Taz, back out the Z-stop screw a couple turns in case there are any differences in height. You don't want to slam the nozzle into your bed. Re-zero the head and re-level your bed after attaching the head. Verify all is working. The new fan should come on the moment you power up your Taz. The cooling fan won't come on until you enable it with pronterface or the LCD panel.

comments.text: Is there anyway to modify the design elegantly to clear the hotendextruder mount left screw, like a pipe thru the hexcooler?
comments.author: mkultra

comments.text: A tube through the duct would reduce airflow.  A hole in the bottom would allow air out and that would possibly influence the part being printed by prematurely cooling it instead of the heat sink on the hot end.
comments.author: mkultra

comments.text: I am not sure what area you are talking about wanting to cool?  The fan shroud STL here is the orange fan shroud shown in the images above.  The lower part of a hot end does NOT get a fan!  Its the hot zone and needs to remain HOT!  A hot end cooling fan is only for the fins located on the upper portion of a hot end.  This is the infeed portion of the hot end and sits above the transition zone (just below the shroud).  This need to be kept cool to minimize filament swelling and pre-heating before the filament reaches the melting area in the lower portion of the hot end.
comments.author: Wolfie

comments.text: Do you have a fan shroud for the lower part of the hot end for this design? The fan mount in your other designs seems to be for another type of hotend

title: Multi-rotor camera rail mount - Tarot compatible

description.text:
Tarot camera rails are 49mm apart. Not exactly the a round number. This mount will take 10mm DIA tubes or rods to attache them to the bottom of most copter frames. It has only one center attachment point on each. Two mounts are required to hold the rails.
The 16mm version takes 16mm OD tube which acts as a vibration insulator. The latest version has an extension for 6mm carbon legs which saves a heap of weight in landing gear.
Secondly there are two different versions of the 16mm rail block.The first has a centering flange and other doesn't. Choose which ever suits your needs. The last is the 10mm version which can take a 10mm carbon tube without dampener. I hope this thingy is as useful to you as it has been for me.

Chase Motor Truck Company had its roots in the manufacture of farm implements. Company founder, Aurin M. Chase, former vice president of the Syracuse Chilled Plow Company, a company that had been in business since 1804, started production of a one-ton truck with an air-cooled, three-cylinder, two-cycle engine. Chase was backed by Paul Bellinger of the Solvay Process Company, Roy Grant of Grant's Hardware and other Syracuse business figures.
That same year, Aurin Chase negotiated sale of the Syracuse Chilled Plow Company to Deere & Company.
Chase had what seemed like a solid idea in the early days of automobile manufacturing, a gasoline-fueled "high wheeler" that could be transformed into either a truck or passenger car.
The company motto in 1912 advertisements was "The emblem of efficiency." According to the company, "Chase trucks are not pleasure cars. They are service vehicles. That increasing numbers of leading business houses everywhere are sending in repeat orders is due to the fact that after an intimate study of motor truck efficiency they are satisfied that the Chase truck is the simplest and most efficient light delivery truck on the market to-day Another variant https://www.myminifactory.com/object/chase-truck-motor-company-moving-car-6317 https://myminifactory.com/object/oldsmobile-curved-dash-7615

Food Hacker? Low on Kitchen estate? Small Budget? Mobile/Ghetto Kitchen? A nomadic Hacker in need of protein rich and vitamin packed food supplement with a very low weight/volume footprint in your backpack, which you can grow on-site? Afraid of the Zombie apocalypse and thinking about solutions for supply needs similar to the nomadic hacker's? Want to personally make a change and stop/reduce eating out-of-local-season import fruit, which would otherwise have to travel up to 12.000 km to get to you but worried about vitamin deficiencies? Try Sprouts. You basically just need seeds, water and a containment/growing environment that produces favorable conditions for the process. Nature does the rest. The SEEDStack is a Proposal/Demonstrator for such an open, integrated, modular and stackable containment/growing system. You can just grab the part files or adapt the model to print your own copies with a 3D printer. No heating or lighting is required, in fact, a dark environment produces better yields. Yum! More details, videos and instructions on the project page of our Lab, it's still WIP but since it's hacked together in OpenSCAD already with parametric design in mind, you can change it however you like. https://apollo.open-resource.org/lab:seedstack Complete source-code, slicing parameters, development and issue tracking: https://github.com/apollo-ng/seedstack Let us know how it went or even better, join our collaborative development process and send a pull-request :) Happy Sprouting. License: CERN OHL 1.2
Unfortunately Thingiverse doesn't carry it in the list. You can also join us in #apollo on Freenode IRC, if you have questions or would like to chat about it.

comments.text: I doubt that I will make this, as I don't have any printable food-ok materials and I don't want to use PLA for growing something inside, but I really like the whole idea. Just the idea of this and the looks is awesome, I really like it.
comments.author: chrisfredriksson

comments.text: If you're having issues with natural/transparent PLA, which generally seems to be considered food-safe, try one of the new PET filaments to be on the absolutely safe side. It would also be great if more manufacturers would offer stainless steel nozzles instead of the brass types. We have covered this in the FAQ on the project's page.

Hi Chron0,
Even if PET is considered food safe, I would doubt many of the Chinese manufacturers actually use food safe practices which would involve not using other chemicals around the filament and the filament preparation area. For all we know, the PET pellets chould be stored next to a container full of rat poison before or after it was extruded. I would also be concerned about making the item because of this possibility. Unfortunately using any kind of locallly made filament which might be more trustworthy is just too expensive. I don't really know why when you consider that plastic pellets can be bought for less than $2 per kilo in bulk but filament costs more than $20 per kilo.
comments.author: chron0

title: PCB Drill Press Stand (with LED light)

description.text:
This is small neat drill press stand designed to use laser printer engines widely sold on ebay/aliexpress.
This project based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:144333 by Mark Benson design with next improvements:
  • Designed for engine body sized L=35-60mm D=30mm
  • Shifted base hole to center drill according new motor diameter
  • Added 3x 3mm super light LED holders focused on drill working area
  • Added PCB with voltage regulator and connector for standard notebook power unit (which is used for drill and light). This can be easily changed on any power source up to 24v (only connector should be changed in this case)
  • Added holes in slider to mount PCB
  • Added hole on left side of fixed sliding wedge for balancing spring/rubber.

• ABS or PLA filament
  • Drill chuck
  • M5 Threaded rod (about 110mm)
  • Threaded rod M8 (about 95mm and 80mm). One is for stand, second is for gear and fixed slider.
  • 6x M8 nut, nyloc (better 8x for stand tightening)
  • 4x 8mm washer
  • 9x M3 18mm bolts
  • 10x M3 nuts
  • 6x 3mm washers
  • 6x 3x12mm screws

• Motor from printer with body diameter 30mm and length between 35-60mm
  • Female-Female du-pont wires 10cm (6x)
  • 3x LED 3mm White
  • 2.54mm 2-wire connector
  • Jack plug (diameters must match your notebook power unit connector)
  • Notebook power unit
  • 2x3 pin header male
  • LM7805 (or LM7812) voltage regulator
  • 0.1uF and 0.33uF capacitors
  • 3x 100 Ohm resistors (or 390 Ohm if LM7812 used)
  • Prototype Board or etched PCB

Overall, it's pretty clear from images and renders how to asemble it. The only moment, is that you need to fix LED inside their mount hole by hot glue gun. Just small spot on each will suit (and it will be easy to remove when needed just apply hot gun needle on that spot). Second moment is that you need to put M3 nuts instead of washers between PCB and a slider. This need to allow bigger space between board and slider for solder joints and SMD components. PCB in Eagle format and more images/details on https://github.com/solival/PcbDrillStand

comments.text:
Hi, thanks for this. I've bought a 28mm high speed motor with a drill chuck up to 4mm and I'm about to mount it.
Printed everything but the base in ABS at 240 C and with the 110 C heated bed, took almost 20 hours. 0/15 mm layer, 0.3 mm nozzle.
I won't use a plastic base, I'd rather take wood or even metal for it.

title: Sega Mega Drive/Genesis case for Sega and EA-style game cartridges

description.text:
I've been collecting some old Sega Mega Drive games, but most of them don't come with cases. There are some mass-produced options for replacement cases, but I don't live in an area where it's practical to get them delivered (they would end up being quite expensive with shipping)  
So I've designed a simple 2-part plastic box to securely hold the cartridge in place, which can be covered with a printed paper sleeve for shelf-display.  
Cartridges licensed/manufactured by Sega are a certain shape and fit sideways in the box (same orientation as the original boxes), the other popular style was designed by Electronic Arts, and fit in the other set of clips. Accolade also made some carts that fit in the EA clips, but there were a few other niche ones that may or may not work.  
I don't have access to any Sega-manufactured carts for the Japan region (which are smaller), but there's a good chance they'd fit in the EA clips, since those carts were designed to be region-free.

Printing tips:
  • The box is designed to be printed extremely roughly (0.3mm layer height), and the roughness covered up with a paper sleeve.
  • The clearance between parts is 1mm on each edge, if you're printing in higher quality the top might be too loose.
  • Print in PET-G or PLA. ABS is a challenge I haven't been able to master with this, it curls too easily.
  • SUPPORT IS REQUIRED "everywhere" on the base box (not just touching the build plate - it's required above the printed base all the way up to the clips).
  • Front/back/wall thickness is 1.2mm (multiple of 0.2mm or 0.3mm), so make sure your "shell" setting is at least 0.6mm - but you still need set infill to 100% for clean interface layers.
  • I've designed mouse-ears into the STL to combat curling - these are removed after printing by wiggling them back and forth to weaken them, then bending to snap off. Clean up with a sharp knife.
  • Requires at least an 8" build area (200mmx180mm)
    • After printing, you will need to make some cover art:
  • Start with a good scan or fanart from eg. [The Cover Project](http://www.thecoverproject.net )
  • The height of the box is 177mm, width of front/back is 128mm, and spines are 25mm
  • Copy the artwork for the spine, and place it on the left and right of both the front cover and the back cover art.
  • Print out the front and back cover onto high-quality photo paper
  • Fold the front cover's spines down, and the back cover's spines up (fold them over your printed box for reference), and glue the spines together to form a sleeve

title: Redesigned K8200/3Drag V2, Build volume 200x200x300 mm

description.text:
(V3 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769805) ( V1 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:764262) Didn't like the original x-carriage.
Will not have time to print and test everything for a while and don't know if parts will hold so going to leave it as work in progress. Added a screw mount for the endstop on the x-carriage by eMotion-Tech (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616/#remixes) for Prusa i3 Rework.
One for T5 belts and the other one for GT2 belts. The 625 bearing for the X-belt and the Y-belt needs a small m5 washer on each side and then one large m5 washer each side like:
(large washer - small washer - bearing - small washer - large washer) Might needs some washers between bearing clamp x, y belt holder.stl and printbed lower carriage.
Added a longer bearing clamp x (bearing clamp x longer.stl) and y belt holder.stl (y belt holder longer.stl) instead. You need:
A K8200 or 3Drag and some extra screw, nuts and washers (m3, m4, m5, m8).
M8 threaded rod about 50 cm to get 300 mm on z.
Zip ties.
Longer feets (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719859). Optional (probably best to get it):
2x Springs for the backlash on (z_holder_endstop.stl) and (z_holder.stl).
Nema 17 stepper motor.
M8 threaded rod.
Coupler
GT2 belts and pulleys.

remixed_from.author: JG094
remixed_from.title: Basic Raspberry Pi B+ Mounting Bracket for Printrbot Simple Metal

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Raspberry Pi Case

description.text:
I wanted to mount my Raspberry Pi on my Printerbot and have a box where all the cables come together. Also I have a heated printbed, so I needed a bigger power supply. So I modified an old XBOX brick, that connects at the top right and passes through the box to the printer. I connected a 12V to 5V converter to this line to power the raspi. There are also holes for the raspi camera cable, a cable to power the external LEDs for the camera (see other thing), and a on/off switch.  
To attach the lid to the case, I used thread inserts in the case. You should be able to just use screws.

I just printed it with the default settings from printrbot, as they worked for everything i printed so far.  
Edit: You might want to make the lid a little bid thicker, as mine is warping because of the rigid cables.

remixed_from.author: nophead
remixed_from.title: Yet Another Prusa Mendel Z Coupling

description.text:
Z coupling 5 mm -> 6.35mm (1/4"), customizable in Customizer. Lately I got obsessed with the z-wobble in my MendelMax 1.5. I already have precision lead screws and didn't want to buy new ones.
I noticed that the motor axis was very stable, but the lead screw itself was wobbling at the couple location. I thought that fixing that wobble may improve wobbling in my prints, and it did! Based on the z-coupling by nophead/Griffin_Nicoll, I updated the model with an adjustable asymmetry. I assumed that the asymmetry is mostly in a single direction. It also has some visual updates and I made it a bit longer to enforce more straightness. This version works with m3 screws and bolts. The grey object has near no wobble, while the orange object still has some wobble. Instructions:
  • Move head up and down with straight coupling. See if the axis goes back and forth (seen from the side). If so, an asymmetric coupling may help.
  • Try values of for instance 0.3 mm and see if the back/forth movement is less or worse. If worse, rotate the coupling and tighten again.
  • It's a lot of experimenting to find your optimal setting.
    • I ended up with:
  • One end a straight coupling
  • Other side has a 0.3mm asymmetry
    • Note:
    z-wobble can easily be confused with z-ribbing. I fixed my z-ribbing by adjusting the steps/mm in my firmware by a tiny bit.
    Original value 2015.748, new value 2020 -> This ensures that all layer thicknesses that are multiple of 0.05 have the same amount of motor steps through all layers.

comments.text: Hi, I have one question. Is it going to work in my Prusa i2 3D printer?
comments.author: ziomosk

comments.text:
Hi,
The prusa i2 probably has a similar coupling? Then it should work.
Good luck!
comments.author: ziomosk

comments.text: Hi, could you make some documentation on customizing this object here? I don't understand the parameter used for which part and I want to use it with metric system
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: Hi, Studding Dia and Shaft Dia are the main settings. Both are in mm's. You can try some values and see what happens in Customizer. Hope this helps.
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: What about the screws that will be used? Let's say I want to use an m4 screw with m4 nuts, where do I change it?
comments.author: Amplivibe

comments.text: Ah that should have been holeR, but I see that doesn't work properly in Customizer. If you have OpenSCAD, you can download the source and do it yourself. I'll try to fix it later on.
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: I opened this script in openscad, the holes for screw seems closed, is that normal?
comments.author: Amplivibe

comments.text: Hi sarf2k4. Yes this is normal. There is a very thin layer that will print as a bridge.
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: I generated the object. My threaded rod is around 7.7mm diameter and motor shaft is 5mm diameter, the object parameter is 7.5 and 5mm, would this parameter be advisable for my rods?
comments.author: Amplivibe

comments.text:
7.5 and 5 mm should be fine - you have to screw it together anyway.
I don't think 5mm or 4.9mm for the motor shaft makes a real difference. The print settings will be more important, that will decide if the object is perfect, too tight or too loose. I would recommend to just try it :-) (I made a dozen of these couplers to try out and finally come to the perfect ones).
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: The thing is, I got limited time today to use someone's printer later, so I wanna make my printer operational asap, been a hectic process where I had to keep doing bed leveling process for about 5 times in 2 weeks already. I just wanted to avoid some useless prints as in the parts were too big to fit as a coupler. At least want to have my printer operational then I will print another with different parameter at home
comments.author: Amplivibe

comments.text: With either setting, it will be functional. Make sure you have M3 bolts and screws that are long enough. Good luck!
comments.author: sarf2k4
